query:
59. Consider the following statements regarding mercury pollution :
1. Gold mining activity is a source of mercury pollution in the world.
2. Coal-based thermal power plants cause mercury pollution.
3. There is no known safe level of exposure to mercury.
How many of the above statements are correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None

solution_notes.summary: The question asks us to evaluate statements regarding mercury pollution, specifically focusing on gold mining, coal-based thermal power plants, and safe exposure levels. All three statements provided are accurate.

sections.title: Mercury Pollution from Gold Mining

content.text: Gold mining activity, particularly artisanal and small-scale gold mining (ASGM), is a significant source of mercury pollution globally. Mercury is used to extract gold from ore through a process called amalgamation.

In ASGM, mercury is mixed with gold-containing materials to form a mercury-gold amalgam. This amalgam is then heated, vaporizing the mercury to isolate the gold. This process releases mercury into the environment.

As described in the supporting content, section 1, mercury pollution in gold mining primarily originates from artisanal and small-scale gold mining (ASGM) where mercury is used to extract gold from ore. The process involves mixing mercury with gold-containing materials, forming a mercury-gold amalgam which is then heated, vaporizing the mercury to obtain the gold, releasing large amounts of mercury into the environment.

sections.title: Mercury Pollution from Coal-Based Thermal Power Plants

content.text: Coal-based thermal power plants are another significant source of mercury pollution. Coal naturally contains trace amounts of mercury.
When coal is burned in these plants, the mercury is released into the atmosphere as a byproduct of combustion. This mercury can then deposit onto land and water, causing pollution.

sections.title: Safe Levels of Exposure to Mercury

content.text: There is no known safe level of exposure to mercury. Mercury is a neurotoxin, and any exposure can pose risks, particularly to pregnant women, infants, and young children.
Even low levels of mercury exposure can lead to developmental and neurological problems. Therefore, efforts are made to minimize human exposure to mercury from all sources.

sections.slide_layout: Title: Safe Levels of Exposure to Mercury. Bullet points explaining why there is no safe level of mercury exposure.

assessment_questions.concept_to_be_assessed: Understanding the dangers of mercury exposure, even at low levels.

sections.title: Conclusion

content.text: All three statements are correct: gold mining and coal-based thermal power plants are sources of mercury pollution, and there is no known safe level of exposure to mercury.
